    Benchmarking the functions

    Matthew Crump

    2019-04-23

    conflictPower-benchmarking-vignette.Rmd
    library(conflictPower)
library(microbenchmark)
    c_nmst <- c(n=10, mu=520, sigma=100, tau=100)
nc_nmst <- c(n=10, mu=500, sigma=100, tau=100)
subjects <- 25

microbenchmark(c_score(c_nmst,nc_nmst),
               c_scores(subjects,c_nmst, nc_nmst),
               c_power(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst),
               times=10)
    pc_power_fast(subjects=10,
   mc_c_nmst = c(80,550,100,100),
   mc_nc_nmst = c(20,500,100,100),
   mnc_c_nmst = c(20,570,100,100),
   mnc_nc_nmst = c(80,500,100,100),
   num_sims = 10000,
   alpha = .05)

pc_power(subjects=10,
   mc_c_nmst = c(80,550,100,100),
   mc_nc_nmst = c(20,500,100,100),
   mnc_c_nmst = c(20,570,100,100),
   mnc_nc_nmst = c(80,500,100,100),
   num_sims = 1000,
   alpha = .05)


microbenchmark(c_power(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst),
               try_power2(1000),
               c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst),
               times=1)

c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst,num_sims=10000)

microbenchmark(
c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst,num_sims=10),
c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst,num_sims=100),
c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst,num_sims=1000),
c_power_fast(subjects,c_nmst,nc_nmst,num_sims=10000),
times=1)


microbenchmark(c_scores(100*1000,c_nmst,nc_nmst), 
               c_scores2(100*1000,c_nmst,nc_nmst),times=1)

microbenchmark(matrix(rnorm(100*1000,0,1),nrow=1000,ncol=100),
               matrix(retimes::rexgauss(100*1000,500,100,100, positive=TRUE),nrow=1000,ncol=100),
               times=5)

try_power <- function(){
  trials <- 20
  subjects <- 100
  c_mat <- matrix(retimes::rexgauss(trials*subjects,500,100,100, positive=TRUE),nrow=subjects,ncol=trials)
  nc_mat <- matrix(retimes::rexgauss(trials*subjects,475,100,100, positive=TRUE),nrow=subjects,ncol=trials)
  diff_mat <- rowMeans(c_mat)-rowMeans(nc_mat)
  t.test(diff_mat)$p.value
}

try_power2 <- function(sims){
  a<-replicate(sims,try_power())
  power <- length(a[a<.05])/sims
  return(power)
}

try_power2(1000)

a<-replicate(1000,try_power())




c_power2 <- function( subjects,
                     c_nmst,
                     nc_nmst,
                     num_sims = 1000,
                     alpha = .05) {

  p_values <- replicate(num_sims,
                        t.test(c_scores(subjects,
                                        c_nmst,
                                        nc_nmst))$p.value)

  power <- length(p_values[p_values < alpha])/num_sims
  return(power)

}

rexgauss_fast <- function (n, mu = 0, sigma = 1, tau = 1, positive = TRUE) 
{
    if (positive) {
            x <- rnorm(n, mu, sigma) + rexp(n, 1/tau)
    }
    else x <- rnorm(n, mu, sigma) + rexp(n, 1/tau)
    return(x)
}


c_score2 <- function(c_nmst = c(n,mu,sigma,tau),
                    nc_nmst = c(n,mu,sigma,tau)){

  conflict <- rexgauss_fast(n=c_nmst[1],
                                mu=c_nmst[2],
                                sigma=c_nmst[3],
                                tau =c_nmst[4],
                                positive = TRUE)

  no_conflict <- rexgauss_fast(n=nc_nmst[1],
                                   mu=nc_nmst[2],
                                   sigma=nc_nmst[3],
                                   tau =nc_nmst[4],
                                   positive = TRUE)

  return(mean(conflict) - mean(no_conflict))
}

c_scores2 <- function(subjects,
                     c_nmst = c(n,mu,sigma,tau),
                     nc_nmst = c(n,mu,sigma,tau)) {

  conflict_scores <- replicate(subjects,
                               c_score2(
                                 c_nmst,
                                 nc_nmst
                               )
  )

  return(conflict_scores)
}

    c_score()

    The c_score function generates a single simulated conflict score based on samples from a specified RT distribution for conflict and no-conflict conditions. The examples below defines the conflict effect as a difference of 100 between the mu parameters, and assumes 10 trials per condition.

    The c_score function samples the specified number of RTs from each distribution, computes the mean for each condition (conflict and no conflict), and returns the difference (conflict - no conflict).

     c_score(c_nmst= c(n=10, mu=600, sigma=100, tau=100),
         nc_nmst= c(n=10, mu=500, sigma=100, tau=100))

    c_scores()

    c_scores() generates n number of conflict scores. This can be useful for simulating n number of subjects in an experiment, or for simulating a sampling distribution of conflictd scores.

    The sampling distribution is useful for understanding the precision of the design for measuring a particular individualâ€™s conflict score. For example, with only 10 trials in each condition, the distribution of possible conflict scores for this subject is very wide.

    x <- c_scores(subjects = 1000,
            c_nmst= c(n=10, 
                      mu=600, 
                      sigma=100, 
                      tau=100),
            nc_nmst= c(n=10, 
                       mu=500, 
                       sigma=100, 
                       tau=100))
mean(x)
sd(x)
hist(x)

    c_power()

    This function computes statistical power to detect a conflict effect using monte carlo simulation.

    c_power(subjects=20,
             c_nmst = c(20,500,100,100),
             nc_nmst = c(20,550,100,100),
             num_sims = 1000,
             alpha = .05)
